title: Opening

author: Craig A. Knoblock, Information Sciences Institute (ISI), University of Southern California

segmentation: Welcome distinguished guests ladies and gentlemen, colleagues and friends.
I'm Craig Knoblock and his conference chair.
It is my pleasure to welcome you to the 2000 Eleven 2011 International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence.
I'm glad you could join us for what promises to be a great conference.
The theme of this year's conference is integrated and embedded artificial intelligence in support of this theme, we have a special track of papers at the conference that focuses on this topic.
We've also invited other conferences, workshops and symposium in specialized areas related to a two AI to Co locate with each kind Barcelona this year before, during or after the conference.
We have eleven such Co located events, and I know that many of you are taking advantage of those other events.
In addition, we have a single track that will run throughout the conference with the best papers from 24 of the top conferences in AI.
This will give you a chance to see some of the best work from the related conferences and provides you with an opportunity to learn about a broad cross section of research.
I hope you will take advantage of this new feature at each kind.
This conference is the 22nd in a series that started in 1969.
The map on the screen shows all the locations in which each guy has been held over the years.

These locations include the US, Canada, Japan, India, Georgia, Mexico, Australia and many countries throughout Europe, but this is the first time in its 42 year history that it has been held in Spain.
You can see on the map that are marked with a red pen, the current location and the location of the Nextage guy which would be held in Beijing, China.
You can also see from the map that there are many countries and even parts of the world where we have never held in each conference.
As the AI community continues to grow throughout the world, there are increasing number of requests to hold each guy in new places.

In response to this demand, each trustees are considering changing each chi to an annual conference in order to continue serving our existing community as well as to grow the air community in other parts of the world.
This issue will be discussed at the International High Society meeting this week.
And individuals are invited to discuss this issue with any of the Sky trustees.

The trustees will make a final decision about this issue on Thursday and announced the results of the closing event on Friday, given that each has always been a biannual conference, we view this as a significant change and we welcome your input on this issue.
This conference has been made possible by the dedicated work of many people, including the conference Committee, each by trustees and officers.
The Local Arrangements Committee, and all of the members of the program Committee.
There are two people that deserve special recognition for the incredible job that they did on the conference this year.
First, I want to knowledge the program chair, Toby Walsh, who worked tirelessly.
Toby worked tirelessly to put together an outstanding technical program.

He went well beyond the Call of Duty, carefully monitoring every step of the review process, creating a new track of best papers, and even writing his own scheduling software to optimize the schedule of the many papers.
Second, I want to acknowledge the local arrangements.

Chair Carlos Sierra, who worked worried about every detail of the local arrangements he recruited and managed an amazing team of people that have done a terrific job in creating a truly memorable conference experience.
I also want to thank also acknowledge the many sponsors who supported each guy this year.
Thank you all very much.

At the conference we have a tradition of honoring prominent AI scientists who have passed away since the previous conference, so it is now my sad duty to communicate the recent deaths of three people, Ray Solomonoff, Sam Royce and David Rumelhart.
Ray Solomonoff passed away in December 2009.
He was born in 1926 in Cleveland, OH, and as a teenager, became captivated with the idea of creating machines that could learn and ultimately think.
He went on to study physics at the University of Chicago and received his Masters degree in 1951.
In 1952, he met Marvin Minsky and John McCarthy.
Four years later, Mr. Salmanov was one of the 10 people that took part in the original Dartmouth Summer Research Project in artificial intelligence, which is now considered the symbol event for AI.
In the early 60s, Mr. Salmanov developed the idea of algorithmic algorithmics probability and went on to pioneer the application of probability theory to solving artificial intelligence problems.
Later he turned his attention to the consequences of artificial intelligence.
In 1985 he wrote a paper that speculated on the effort it would take to develop a machine with many times the intelligence of a group of humans.
Mr. Salmanov was fiercely independent and remains self-employed for much of his life, taking a variety of visiting scholar positions in various places in the world.
Sam Royce died in January 2010.
Doctor Royce was outstanding scholar whose research in machine learning and statistical signal processing have had a profound impact within the machine learning community and beyond.
His mathematical contributions span an extraordinary wide range of areas including dimensionality reduction, signal processing, machine learning, and statistics.
He applied his theoretical insights and computational expertise with enormous energy and great practical success to fields as diverse as astrophysics, speech recognition, and proteomics.
Doctor Royce received his PhD from the California Institute of Technology in 1999 after two years as a research fellow in the Gatsby Unit at University College London.
He joined the Department of Computer Science at the University of Toronto in 2009.
He joined the Courant Institute at New York University.

He received many prestigious awards, including a Sloan Research Fellowship of Premiers Research Excellence Award and Appointments as a Canada Research Chair and a Fellow of the Canadian Institute for Advanced Research.
Doctor Rama heart passed away in March of this year after a long battle with picks disease.
He was a pioneer in the field of cognitive neuroscience and explored the concept of connectionism, the idea that no single neuron in the brain does its job alone in processing information.

Doctor Roma Hearts computer simulations of perception gave scientists some of the first testable models of neural processing and proved helpful in the development of machine learning and artificial intelligence.
In collaboration with Jay McClelland, he created computer models in the 70s and 80s that simulated human perception language understanding memory in a wide range of other cognitive tasks.

He and Doctor McClellan wrote parallel, distributed processing explorations in the microstructure of cognition of book that brought the concept of connectionism to a wider audience of psychologists, neuroscientists, and computer scientists.
Doctor Rama hard earned his doctorate at Stanford in 1967 and spent 20 years on the faculty of the University of California in San Diego.

Before returning to Stanford in 1987, Doctor Rama Hart received many professional awards, including a MacArthur Fellowship and the American Psychological Association's distinguished Scientific Contribution Award.

In 2000, the Glushko Samuelson Foundation established the Roma Heart Prize $100,000 award given annually to scientists who make a significant contribution to the theoretical foundations of human cognition.
On behalf of the Skype participants, we offer our deep felt condolences to them.
Families and Friends of Ray Solomonoff, Sam, Royce, and Race and David Rumelhart.
And now please join me for a minute of silence in their honor.
Thank you.
